repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Industrial Energy Conservation and
            Rationalization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The loan for the Energy Conservation and
            Rationalization Project for Peru, though approved by the
            Board in 1985, was never signed. In 1986, about a year after
            approval, the Bank was reluctant to sign because it no
            longer considered Peru creditworthy. The Bank believed that
            the 1986 economic boom was unsustainable and had fundamental
            reservations about the Government's economic policies.
            However, the fragile Bank-Government relations at the time
            made it difficult for the Bank to withdraw the loan
            immediately. In February 1987, management decided to
            postpone withdrawal in view of the Government's
            expressed interest in the project. However, there were
            indications that the Government appeared prepared to default
            on its World Bank debt. In May 1987, Peru suspended debt
            service payments to the Bank, causing the Bank to suspend
            disbursements on all loans to Peru. Still, the Bank took no
            action at that time on this relatively small project. In
            July 1988, the Borrower and the Bank agreed that the
            operation be withdrawn. Still, the project concept and
            design were so well developed and the country priority and
            commitment were so high that the project was fully
            implemented even though the Bank funding failed to
            materialize. The project continued to enjoy support among
            the Government and is expected to make a significant
            contribution to institution building and human capital
            development in the energy sector. The main lessons learned
            from the preparation and appraisal of this project were the
            importance of: (i) finding support at the highest Government
            level to ensure the acceptance and success of a project;
            (ii) developing a close working relationship with industry,
            and ensuring its participation in the benefits of the
            project; (iii) charging fees for the services provided; and
            (iv) setting up a supervisory institution that is not part
            of the Government, so as to avoid the exigencies of bureaucracy.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Industrial Energy Conservation and
            Rationalization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Energy Conservation and
            Rationalization Project will establish a Center for Energy
            Conservation to assist the industrial sector in Peru in
            reducing energy costs through conservation and
            rationalization, including the carrying out of energy
            audits, development of energy conservation and
            rationalization legislation, carrying out an incentives
            study for energy savings, preparation of manuals and
            handbooks on energy saving measures in energy-intensive
            sub-sectors and training. The implementation of the Project
            will be carried out with the assistance of the Energy
            Conservation Department (ECD) that will be created by
            PETROPERU exclusively for purposes of the Project. The
            relationship between PETROPERU and the Center will be
            detailed in a Management Contract to be approved by the Bank.
